natural problem: Find the sum of $111_4+323_4+132_4$. Express your answer in base $4$.
natural solution: Since $1_4+3_4+2_4=12_4$, we carry over the $1$. Then we have $1_4+1_4+2_4+3_4=13_4$, so we carry over another $1$. For the leftmost column, we have $1_4+1_4+3_4+1_4=12_4$. In column format, this reads $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & & _{1} &_{1}&\\ & & & 1& 1 & 1_4\\ & & & 3 & 2 & 3_4\\& & + & 1 & 3 & 2_4\\ \cline{2-6} & & 1 & 2 & 3& 2_4\\ \end{array} $$The sum is $\boxed{1232_4}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a = int_of_base 4 '111'"
and h1 : "b = int_of_base 4 '323'"
and h2 : "c = int_of_base 4 '132'"
shows  "int_to_base 4 (a + b + c) = '1232'"

(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 Since $1_4+3_4+2_4=12_4$, we carry over the $1$. Then we have $1_4+1_4+2_4+3_4=13_4$, so we carry over another $1$. For the leftmost column, we have $1_4+1_4+3_4+1_4=12_4$. In column format, this reads $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & & _{1} &_{1}&\\ & & & 1& 1 & 1_4\\ & & & 3 & 2 & 3_4\\& & + & 1 & 3 & 2_4\\ \cline{2-6} & & 1 & 2 & 3& 2_4\\ \end{array} $$The sum is $\boxed{1232_4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a = int_of_base 4 '111'"
and h1 : "b = int_of_base 4 '323'"
and h2 : "c = int_of_base 4 '132'"
shows  "int_to_base 4 (a + b + c) = '1232'"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Add the base-4 numbers 111, 323, and 132. What is their sum, expressed as a base-4 number? The final answer is 1232.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem

assumes h0 : "a = numeral (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit1 Num.One)))"

and h3 : "sum = numeral (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit1 Num.One))))"

 *)

theorem

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes base :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "base = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. to_base_4 (n::nat) = (if n < base then [n] else to_base_4 (n div base) @ [n mod base])"
shows  "to_base_4 (from_base_4 [1, 1, 1] + from_base_4 [3, 2, 3] + from_base_4 [1, 3, 2]) = [1, 2, 3, 2]"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of $111_4+323_4+132_4$. Express your answer in base $4$. The final Answer is 1232_4
 ### Proof
 Since $1_4+3_4+2_4=12_4$, we carry over the $1$. Then we have $1_4+1_4+2_4+3_4=13_4$, so we carry over another $1$. For the leftmost column, we have $1_4+1_4+3_4+1_4=12_4$. In column format, this reads $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & & _{1} &_{1}&\\ & & & 1& 1 & 1_4\\ & & & 3 & 2 & 3_4\\& & + & 1 & 3 & 2_4\\ \cline{2-6} & & 1 & 2 & 3& 2_4\\ \end{array} $$The sum is $\boxed{1232_4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes base :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "base = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. to_base_4 (n::nat) = (if n < base then [n] else to_base_4 (n div base) @ [n mod base])"
shows  "to_base_4 (from_base_4 [1, 1, 1] + from_base_4 [3, 2, 3] + from_base_4 [1, 3, 2]) = [1, 2, 3, 2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the base-4 representation of the sum of the numbers represented by the base-4 digits $111$, $323$, and $132$. The final answer is $1232$.
